where $n=\frac{N}{V}$ is the particle number density and $N$ is the number of particles in a co-moving volume $V.$ The scalar $\theta=u^{\mu}_{;\mu}$ represents the fluid expansion, particle flow vector is defined by $N^{\mu}=nu^{\mu},$ $\Gamma$ represents the particle creation rate and $\dot{n}$ by notation represents $n_{,\mu}u^{\mu}.$ It should be noted that there is some dissipation effect due to particle creation and effectively there is non-equillibrium thermodynamics [30]. Also, particle creation $(\Gamma>0)$ or annihilation $\Gamma<0)$ is characterised by the sign of $\Gamma.$

 We shall now relate the particle creation parameter $\Gamma$ to the dissipative pressure $\Pi_{1}$ of the present work. The Gibb's equation can be written as [27-30]

prevtext: where $s$ is the entropy per particle, $T$ is the fluid temperature and Clausius relation is taken care of. Using conservation equations (\ref{econsv1}) and (\ref{nconsv}), a simple algebra gives the entropy variation from the above Gibb's equation, as [29-31]

nexttext: It shows that for isentropic thermal process dissipative pressure is completely determined by particle creation rate. Equivalently, the physical process may be considered as a perfect fluid with barotropic equation of state $p_{1}=\omega_{1}\rho_{1}$ and particle creation mechanism causes the dissipative phenomena. In this context one should keep in mind, that in adiabatic system entropy production is caused by particle creation and by enlargement of the phase space due to expansion of the universe. Thus the present non-equilibrium configuration is not the usual one, rather a state with equilibrium properties as well. Now eliminating $\Pi_{1},$ from equation (\ref{pi}) and the field equation (\ref{field5}) (for simplicity we assumed a flat model for space-time and hence $b_{0}$ is assumed to be zero) and using the equation of state parameter $\omega_{1}=\frac{p_{1}}{\rho_{1}},$ we find that the particle creation parameter is related to the evolution of the universe as

Thus the present non-equilibrium configuration is not the usual one, rather a state with equilibrium properties as well. }{2}\int\exp\{\frac{1+\omega_{1}}{2}\int\Gamma dt\}dt}" display="block"><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>

prevtext: and consequently

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E17.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="a=a_{0}\left[H_{0}+\frac{3(1+\omega_{1})}{2}\int\exp\left\{\left(\frac{1+%
\omega_{1}}{2}\right)\int\Gamma dt\right\}dt\right]^{2/3(1+\omega_{1})}" display="block"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: Hence the above cosmological solution describes a scenario of emergent universe. Also in the above asymptotic limit the energy densities of the two fluid components take the form:

}a_{0}=a_{i}~{}\text{as}~{}t\rightarrow-\infty" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>→</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mtext>as</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E18.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle H\simeq 0,~{}a\simeq a_{i}~{}\text{for}~{}t\ll 0" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>≃</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>≃</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mtext>for</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>≪</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle H\simeq\frac{\Gamma_{0}}{3},~{}a\simeq a_{0}\left(\frac{3}{%
\Gamma_{0}}\right)^{2/3(1+\omega_{1})}\exp\left(\frac{1}{3}\Gamma_{0}t\right),%
~{}\text{for}~{}t\gg 0." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>≃</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>≃</mo><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mtext>for</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>≫</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Also for equation of state parameter $\omega_{r}>0$ at spatial infinity (i.e. $r\rightarrow \infty$) the present inhomogeneous model describing a flat FRW universe, as expected gives $\rho_{2}\rightarrow 0.$ Thus in the spatial asymptotic limit the present inhomogeneous model becomes homogeneous and isotropic FRW universe supported by a single perfect fluid with dissipative effect. It is worthy to mention that for such model, emergent scenario has already been discussed in reference [20]. Normally, in emergent models of universe, there is a phase of Einstein static model in infinite past followed by a period of inflationary expansion. Usually inflationary phase is described by a scalar field (inflaton) having self interacting potential. However, in the present problem, if the homogeneous fluid is not phantom in nature (that is $1+\omega_{1}>0$) then the universe is always in a state of super-inflation (i.e. $\dot{H}>0$). Further, for $t=-\epsilon$ with $|\epsilon|<<1$ we have
prevtext: Hence the above cosmological solution describes a scenario of emergent universe. Also in the above asymptotic limit the energy densities of the two fluid components take the form:

1/\omega_{r})}}{a_{0}^{2}(H_{0})^{4/3(1+\omega_{1})}}=\rho_{i}r^{-(3+1/\omega_%
{r})}~{}\text{as}~{}t\rightarrow-\infty" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>→</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>r</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>a</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>r</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mtext>as</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E19.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle~{}\rho_{1}\simeq 0,~{}\rho_{2}\simeq\rho_{i}r^{-(3+1/\omega_{r})%
}~{}\text{for}~{}t\ll 0" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo>≃</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>≃</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>r</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mtext>for</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>≪</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle~{}\rho_{1}\simeq\frac{\Gamma_{0}^{2}}{3},~{}\rho_{2}\simeq\rho_{%

\exp\left(-\frac{2}{3}\Gamma_{0}t\right)~{}\text{for}~{}t\gg 0." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo>≃</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>≃</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>r</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>r</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mtext>for</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>≫</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
a phase of exponential expansion (inflationary era) without any inflaton. Particle creation mechanism drives the inflationary epoch. Therefore, a scenario of emergent universe is possible for inhomogeneous  space-time model. Finally as a remark we mention that the present model has the basic features of steady state theory of {\it Fred Hoyle et.al} [32, 33] and closely resembles with it.

prevtext: Also for equation of state parameter $\omega_{r}>0$ at spatial infinity (i.e. $r\rightarrow \infty$) the present inhomogeneous model describing a flat FRW universe, as expected gives $\rho_{2}\rightarrow 0.$ Thus in the spatial asymptotic limit the present inhomogeneous model becomes homogeneous and isotropic FRW universe supported by a single perfect fluid with dissipative effect. It is worthy to mention that for such model, emergent scenario has already been discussed in reference [20]. Normally, in emergent models of universe, there is a phase of Einstein static model in infinite past followed by a period of inflationary expansion. Usually inflationary phase is described by a scalar field (inflaton) having self interacting potential. However, in the present problem, if the homogeneous fluid is not phantom in nature (that is $1+\omega_{1}>0$) then the universe is always in a state of super-inflation (i.e. $\dot{H}>0$). Further, for $t=-\epsilon$ with $|\epsilon|<<1$ we have
